terrain.surface: Gravel roads through New Hampshire countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local New Hampshire event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Raid Rockingham is a local event in New Hampshire—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The New Hampshire countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local New Hampshire gravel race. Worth it for New Hampshire/Northeast riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to New Hampshire—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better New Hampshire races: Rasputitsa, D2R2.

logistics.lodging_strategy: SE New Hampshire has good lodging options.
logistics.food: SE New Hampshire has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: New Hampshire summer weather is variable.
New Hampshire rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

topics.weather: Riding in variable New Hampshire weather

logistics.explanation: Nick Digangi had the opportunity to do recon rides of the course, which worked in his favor for pacing strategy. The event offers route flexibility - riders can switch from 60-mile to 45-mile at the mile 20 split, and organizers make the decision for anyone reaching that point after 11:30 AM. Staged starts group similarly-paced riders together based on self-seeding during registration.

length.explanation: Nick Digangi started fading at mile 50 and experienced severe cramping in his quads and hamstrings, needing Clif Blocks for relief. His strategy was clear: "Pace myself. I have a love/hate relationship with all gravel/dirt roads, as they tend sap a lot of energy out of me." The 50-mile distance hits that middle ground where fitness gaps become apparent. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: The rail trail section starts with "3-4 miles of relatively smooth packed dirt and gravel that you can easily navigate on a road bike with 28, 25 or even 23c tires," but the final 2-3 miles were "severely chewed up by what looked to be at least a half-dozen sets of horse tracks." Bikearama called this the "grumpiest section of the entire route," requiring 34c cyclocross tires. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The "Cat 5 climb is tougher and seems to go on longer than the vertical would lead you to believe." Nick Digangi found himself "in some trouble early on" during the Nottingham Square Road climb with its "mix of spongy dirt roads and punchy gradients," though he still managed his second-best time on that segment. The 3,500 feet over 50 miles delivers rolling punishment rather than sustained suffering. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Early June in New Hampshire typically delivers mild conditions, though Dame Road was being graded in late May with "two inches of beach-soft sand/dirt/gravel" creating challenging riding conditions. The course composition of approximately 30% gravel interspersed with pavement sections means weather impacts vary significantly by surface type throughout the route. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Southeast New Hampshire peaks well under 1,000 feet above sea level, making altitude a non-factor. The highest points on course offer rolling New England terrain rather than mountain vistas, with Durham Point and the Rockingham Recreational Trail representing typical low-elevation gravel riding. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Bikearama found the course "surprisingly challenging" and had "no idea you could link so many together to form such a rolling, challenging loop." Dame Road offered the "bipolar experience of ripping up some solidly-packed, smooth-as-silk dirt road" before hitting extended sections of beach-soft sand. The course connects remote gravel sections through Deerfield and Nottingham areas that riders discover rather than expect.

prestige.explanation: Started in 2012 with about 75 riders from a construction zone behind Newmarket Mills, now hosting 450+ riders annually. The event explicitly states it's "absolutely not" a race but "a personal challenge ride" where "riders of all abilities are encouraged to participate and complete the route at their own pace." No competitive structure or notable winners after over a decade of operation.

race_quality.explanation: The staged start system groups riders by self-reported pacing, and route flexibility allows mid-ride distance changes at the mile 20 split. Organizers provide clear cutoff guidance and experienced ride guides for the "Intro to Gravel" category. After 12+ years, they've developed solid infrastructure, though the emphasis remains on personal challenge rather than competitive racing.

experience.explanation: The course "does a great job of interspersing 1-3 mile long sections of dirt/gravel road with longer pavement sections," creating varied riding experiences. Bikearama experienced everything from "carving alpine ski turns on fresh corduroy" on smooth packed dirt to slogging through sand-covered sections. The mix of Rockingham Recreational Trail and rural roads delivers diverse New England gravel terrain.

community.explanation: The finish at Stone Church Music Club features "cold craft beer on tap and some tasty grub" with the post-ride party running 11 AM to 2 PM. Nick Digangi noted the "nice little shindig with plenty of food, water, and 'adult sodas' (all thanks to Smuttynose)" where "everyone was able to relax and chat it up with our spandexed brethren." Independent Fabrication notes "there's beer, bikes, and bike swag involved."

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 50-100 riders, the event markets itself as welcoming "riders of all abilities" with an "Intro to Gravel" category using experienced ride guides and a "no-drop approach." The philosophy emphasizes personal challenge over competition, with no prize structure or competitive categories. After a decade-plus of operation, it attracts recreational riders rather than competitive depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: The post-ride party at Stone Church Music Club includes craft beer and food, plus the event provides route flexibility and experienced guides for beginners. Independent Fabrication partnership adds bike industry credibility, and the 12+ years of operation means organizers have refined the experience. "There's beer, bikes, and bike swag involved, so… yeah, kind of hard for it not to be" fun, as they put it.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Newmarket, New Hampshire sits between Manchester and Portsmouth, avoiding Boston-area premiums while maintaining airport access. The event recommends 32-35mm tires, and riders report success with standard gravel setups - one used "32mm Gravel King tires, tubed, inflated 70-80psi" throughout. Small-town logistics typically mean reasonable lodging and parking costs for early June dates. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
